text: while human rights is a burning concern
in in the West they don't quite resonate
the same way here in China the party has
succeeded in some ways as framing human
rights as you know quite differently
than in the West emphasizing the right
to housing the right to food the right
to work and on those friends the party
can claim that they've made great
strides in the last 30 years back in
February when cgmp in visitor United
States and met with Obama he gave a very
standard Chinese government answer on
yuen Rights which is saying yes there's
room for improvement but the United
States also has its human rights
problems so there's very little hope
that he's going to change the party line
on this on this very sensitive issue
lika Chang who was slated to become the
premier does have a bit of a human
rights record when he was governor and
in party chief of unknown province he
presided over a scandal in which the
blood supply was contaminated with HIV
infecting thousands of people his
response was to crack down on activists
who were trying to push the government
to take action and also cracking down on
journalists who were trying to expose
the scandal Tibet remains one of the
most contentious and problematic issues
for the party in the last year there's
been a rash of self-immolations among
Tibetans of nearly 50 at this point
there's so little known about Xi
Jinping's record that people point to
the relationship his father had with the
Dalai Lama back in the 1950s when he was
a vice premier they apparently had a
very warm relationship it speaks volumes
to how little hope there is that people

what is a very contentious issue in
